column1: This project is part of a Federal Ministry for Education and Research (BMBF) funded research project which aims to develop the social amoeba Dictyostelium discoideum into a production platform for secondary metabolites of pharmaceutical importance..

The successful candidate will assist in the construction of multi-gene expression plasmids and the establishment of CRISPR/Cas tools for strain engineering of the social amoeba Dictyostelium discoideum and will help to develop methods to measure and enhance the production of heterologous secondary metabolites.
The main topics of the project may include:
• Metabolic engineering of D. discoideum to enhance the production of biochemical precursors for polyketide production

column2: automated screening and processing of production strains of D. discoideum

column1: EMBL appoints group leaders from early on in their career and provides a very supportive environment for your first independent position in order to achieve your research goals. The initial “Lead your Lab” management training is provided for all incoming group leaders.

The SCB Unit at EMBL offers access to an outstanding integrated structural biology environment that includes a particularly well equipped cryo-electron microscopy facility. The Unit also interacts closely with the EMBL Imaging Centre that offers access to a broad spectrum of electron and light microscopy technologies with special emphasis on correlative approaches. Further information about research in the SCB Unit and at EMBL can be found at the EMBL web page.

column1: We are looking for an outstanding individual to drive a visionary synthetic biology project poised to make an impact in oncology. With its emphasis on well-characterized and standardized parts
column2: synthetic biology is considered the engineering approach to building molecular systems. It enables the creation of entirely new molecular functionality in a modular and systematic fashion. Computational experts in the hosting lab will support the design of those circuits through data analysis
column3: mathematical modeling and machine learning. The project is a joint venture cooperation between TU Darmstadt and Belgian Biotech Studio

column1: Max Planck Institute for Chemical Ecology (MPICE)

The department of Natural Product Biosynthesis (Prof. Dr. Sarah E. O’Connor) at the Max Planck Institute for Chemical Ecology in Jena invites highly motivated candidates to apply for a three-year PhD position to study alkaloid biosynthesis
Plants produce countless chemically diverse natural products
column2: or specialized metabolites. Alkaloids are a type of natural product that are widely used as medicines. If we discover the biosynthetic genes and enzymes that are responsible for the production of these medicinally important alkaloids
column3: then we can use synthetic biology or engineering approaches to enable better access to these medicines. Ipecac alkaloids have been widely used pharmacological agents for many years. Interestingly
column4: these compounds occur in two evolutionary distant plants suggesting that the biosynthetic pathways evolved independently; in other words
column5: nature developed two different biosynthetic pathways for these molecules.

column1: The aim of this PhD project is to discover the genes of the biosynthetic pathways of ipecac alkaloids in these two distantly related medicinal plant species. Then
column4: and recombined using state-of-the-art plant-based production platforms. The PhD candidate will use cutting-edge metabolomic and transcriptomic approaches to identify enzyme candidates
column5: screen for activities
column6: characterize active enzymes in vitro and in vivo
column7: and reconstitute both natural and synthetic pathways.
